questions.prompt: Which of the following is a functional requirement?
options: The system shall respond within 2 seconds
The system shall allow users to reset their password
The system shall support 10,000 concurrent users
The system shall be available 99.9% of the time
questions.explanation: Functional requirements describe what the system should do. Password reset is a specific function. The others are non-functional requirements about performance and reliability.

options: A requirement about what the system does
A requirement about how well the system performs
A requirement that can be ignored
questions.explanation: Non-functional requirements specify quality attributes like performance, security, usability, and reliability - how well the system performs its functions.

questions.prompt: Which elicitation technique involves observing users in their work environment?
questions.explanation: Ethnography involves observing users in their natural work environment to understand their actual practices and needs.

questions.prompt: What is the main purpose of requirements elicitation?
options: To discover and gather requirements from stakeholders
questions.explanation: Requirements elicitation is the process of discovering and gathering requirements from stakeholders through various techniques.

questions.prompt: Which stakeholder is typically most concerned with functional requirements?
questions.explanation: End users are primarily concerned with functional requirements - what the system can do for them to accomplish their tasks.

questions.prompt: A well-formed user story follows the template: "As a ___, I want ___, so that ___". What goes in the third blank?
questions.explanation: The third part of a user story explains the business value or benefit - why the user wants this feature.

questions.prompt: What does the acronym INVEST stand for in the context of user stories?
options: Independent, Negotiable, Valuable, Estimable, Small, Testable
Integrated, Necessary, Verified, Executable, Scalable, Traceable
Iterative, Nominal, Valid, Exact, Simple, Technical
Initial, Notable, Verified, Essential, Specific, Timely
questions.explanation: INVEST is a mnemonic for qualities of good user stories: Independent, Negotiable, Valuable, Estimable, Small, and Testable.

questions.prompt: What are acceptance criteria in user stories?
options: Specific conditions that must be met for the story to be considered complete
questions.explanation: Acceptance criteria define specific, testable conditions that must be satisfied for the user story to be considered done.

questions.prompt: Which document type is most formal and detailed for requirements specification?
questions.explanation: An SRS (Software Requirements Specification) is a formal, comprehensive document that details all functional and non-functional requirements.

questions.prompt: What is the purpose of requirements prioritization?
options: To determine which requirements to implement first based on value and constraints
questions.explanation: Requirements prioritization helps teams decide which requirements to implement first based on business value, risk, dependencies, and resource constraints.

questions.prompt: What is the difference between verification and validation?
options: Verification checks if we built the product right; validation checks if we built the right product
Verification is for testing; validation is for requirements
Verification is done by users; validation is done by developers
questions.explanation: Verification asks "Did we build the product right?" (meets specifications), while validation asks "Did we build the right product?" (meets user needs).

questions.prompt: Which technique can help validate requirements with stakeholders?
questions.explanation: Prototyping and demonstrations allow stakeholders to see and interact with a representation of the system, helping validate that requirements are correct.

options: The ability to trace requirements from origin through implementation and testing
Measuring how fast requirements are implemented
questions.explanation: Requirements traceability links requirements to their sources and tracks them through design, implementation, and testing.

questions.prompt: Why is requirements management important throughout the project lifecycle?
options: Requirements often evolve, and changes must be controlled and communicated
It is not important after initial gathering
Only managers need to know requirements
questions.explanation: Requirements management is crucial because requirements frequently change, and these changes must be controlled, analyzed, and communicated to all stakeholders.

options: The rate at which requirements change over time
questions.explanation: Requirements volatility measures how frequently requirements change during the project. High volatility indicates unstable or evolving requirements.
